pullRequest.body:
This is one in a series of PRs rewriting most checks from `lint-style.py` in Lean.
This PR moves the check for copyright headers and authors: the check has been rewritten anew (and is hopefully simpler to understand now); this has made it stricter in various places. The necessary adjustments have been made in #13212 and #13247.

This PR also adds a `nolints` file for text-based linters.

--------

This linter is slightly slower than the Python linter: in local testing,
- I believe the Python linter took about 0.6s
- running just `lake exe lint_style` with a no-op linter (incrementing a counter on each file) takes 0.4s
(`time lake exe lint_style` reports `real	0m0,404s; user	0m0,254s; sys	0m0,070s`; this is the second time when no re-compilation is needed)
- with the copyright linter, it takes 0.8s
Any insight into minimising the no-op overhead is welcome (but almost surely out of scope for this PR).

:v: grunweg can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

Thanks for the review! Since CI passes now, let me bors it already:
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9633540266/job/26568072039)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9633540266/job/26568072235)
nit: this, and most of the other names in the file, do not match the usual naming conventions.
Indeed, you're right. Addressed.
I think you should do this here, so that users only have one script to run.

I tried this: as-is, this fails - as this "lint style" workflow then needs to install lake.
Is having separate "lint style" and "build mathlib" steps important, or would "it's all in the build mathlib step" be an acceptable long-term outcome? If the latter, this is only an intermediate state.
Upon second thought, the step only need the `lint_style` executable; adding that is not too bad. I have done this now.
I'd argue that having support for the style exceptions in nolints is a prerequisite for rewriting these linters.

In principle, I wholeheartedly agree: indeed, I have implemented parsing style exceptions and updating their exceptions file. I am happy to add it to this PR, if you prefer. I origininally did not, to makes this PR land faster.

I think parsing style exceptions or updating them is essential for rewriting *this* linter:
- there's no reason new copyright exceptions should get added
(This is different from e.g. the large file linter `ERR_NUM_LIN`, where exceptions are an accepted transient state.)
- all existing copyright headers pass the Python lint
- these hard-coded exceptions are one-off cases where the rewritten linter is too strict
Both of them are not hard to fix (but make the code more complicated): do you really care to get this fixed now?
Fair enough, I have implemented this now.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: rewrite the copyright header check in Lean

source.title: [Tracking PR] feat: rewrite most style linters in Lean
